qas.question: What does finding a difference in disease prevalence between two socially defined groups not necessarily imply?
What do some research suggest medical practices should maintain their focus on?
What is a risk of overemphasizing genetic contributions to health issues?
What is makes more of a difference than race in health outcomes for "race specific" diseases?
What have some studies found patients reluctant to accept in medical practice?

context: Other researchers point out that finding a difference in disease prevalence between two socially defined groups does not necessarily imply <a0_0>genetic causation of the difference<a0_0/>. They suggest that medical practices should maintain their focus on <a1_0>the individual<a1_0/> rather than an individual's membership to any group. They argue that overemphasizing genetic contributions to health disparities carries various risks such as <a2_0>reinforcing stereotypes<a2_0/>, promoting racism or ignoring the contribution of non-genetic factors to health disparities. International epidemiological data show that <a3_0>living conditions<a3_0/> rather than race make the biggest difference in health outcomes even for diseases that have "race-specific" treatments. Some studies have found that patients are reluctant to accept <a4_0>racial categorization<a4_0/> in medical practice.
